{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3418836,"name":"","username":"TheSnowHatHero","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thesnowhathero/{size}/231822_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-28T19:14:45.910Z","cooked":"

CAD (rest of intake is currently unfinished)

Hey everyone! I’m looking for feedback on an intake roller system I designed a bit ago. It theoretically offers light weight and easy assembly/maintenance.

Screen Shot 2024-08-28 at 2.05.09 PM1448×1182 69.2 KB

Blue arrow is a 0.75" OD 0.25" ID 0.28" width bearing. The current design has it retained by being clamped between two polycarbonate plates, but it could easily use something else (i.e., a bearing hat).

Green arrow is a 3/8" OD aluminum tube with the ID drilled out to 0.25". It looks slanted in the screenshot because of the background; it’s not. It exists because I was worried about the 3D printed part breaking if it was extended out to contact the bearing inner race, since there would be very little material there, as well as having shear forces going across layer lines.

Pink arrow is a high-infill ABS timing pulley (the interference marks are from a simplified belt). Yellow arrow is a 1/4-20 heat-set insert. Red arrow is a VEX grip tube held to the printed part with button head self-drilling screws.

The rest of the intake has the same setup with various forms of timing pulleys and/or 10dp herringbone gears.

Edit: spelling, grammar

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-08-28T19:20:25.621Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":88,"reads":353,"readers_count":352,"score":540.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":470409,"topic_slug":"requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.vexrobotics.com/intake-components.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":14},{"url":"https://cad.onshape.com/documents/92eec9936b9bb40bcf2fc16b/w/712bf989c96b2296d98bb8d1/e/14437aedd464538025056c0d?renderMode=0&uiState=66cf71f732c5592910b032d3","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Onshape","clicks":13}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55003,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2502 Engineering Captain"},"post_url":"/t/requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system/470409/1","custom_user_title":"2502 Engineering Captain","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3418844,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-28T19:30:40.997Z","cooked":"

Looks reasonable to me. My only thoughts:

  • why such a long spacer (green arrow). I could understand if it was long enough to reach the heat-set insert, or short enough just to space the 3D printed pulley from the bearing. But I can’t see the reasoning for this in-between length
  • I would make the pulley as large as possible, while being smaller than the 2" tube OD. Larger pulley means less force on the 3D printed teeth.
  • As with all designs of this type, the risk is that the internal thread comes loose or breaks free from the 3D print. In that case, it becomes really difficult to disassemble. Caveat emptor.
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-08-28T19:30:40.997Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":303,"readers_count":302,"score":115.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":470409,"topic_slug":"requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system","display_username":"Brendan Simons, 5406","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system/470409/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3418847,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-28T19:42:40.764Z","cooked":"

I think @nuclearnerd hit some good points. In general, I like the idea (and assume this is just one end and the other end is essentially a mirror of this).

Like the aluminum tubing idea. As far as length, you want enough sticking into the part to be able to resist any bending forces from just immediately loosening it. How much? Off the top, I might consider having it inserted into the 3D print on the order of 2-3x the distance it sticks out. This is more of an empirical thing than a formula I can point to but it seems to satisfy my mental model of being better able to withstand radial forces on the roller by spreading them over a larger area in the 3D print and reducing the effective lever arm of the length that sticks out versus the inserted length.

I think his last point is a really good one. One way to avoid this is to thread directly into the 3D print. If the threaded insert comes lose, this thing is gonna be a bear to get apart. If the threads in the 3D printed part strip, you’ll be able to get it apart and get that bolt out.

I love threaded inserts but they might become the source of anguish in this case.

Nice design - feel a sense of calm looking at it because you’re using the bearing the way it should be and everything can assemble nice and snug and still spin freely.

Nice shootin’ Tex!

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-08-28T19:45:56.261Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":281,"readers_count":280,"score":71.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":470409,"topic_slug":"requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system","display_username":"Chris Herzog","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":22221,"username":"nuclearnerd","name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40142,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]"},"post_url":"/t/requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system/470409/3","custom_user_title":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3418852,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-28T19:55:17.029Z","cooked":"

One other thing to keep in mind regarding maintenance, if the roller has this on each end, it’s essentially captive because the aluminum tubing sticks out into the bearing retainer so this isn’t just a “pull the the bolt on each end and lift it out”.

Loose spacers can be a real issue when assembling some things but it might be worth the pain to not use the tubing inserts in the 3D print and just have a loose spacer. That will allow you to pull the bolts and them slide the roller out.

Assembling will be a bit more of a pain to get the bolt, the loose spacer, and the roller aligned.

But it will eliminate the need to have to separate the support plates holding the bearings on each end to insert or remove the roller.

Your call as to how often you think you might need to do that or how complicated doing a partial disassembly / assembly of the support plates is to replace the roller.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-08-28T19:58:01.316Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":217,"readers_count":216,"score":63.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470409,"topic_slug":"requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system","display_username":"Chris Herzog","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40142,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]"},"post_url":"/t/requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system/470409/4","custom_user_title":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3418891,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-28T21:20:33.670Z","cooked":"

I think you can convert the aluminum spacer to 3DP without a lot of risk. There isn’t actually shear there; that’s taken up by the bolt. What’s going to happen is that the bolt is going to try and embed in the pulley as it rotates relative to the pulley axis.
A conical protrusion will optimize your stresses. Make sure you contact as much of the inner race as you can, and consider a metal washer on there to increase the contact area with the plastic.
Using a bolt with an unthreaded section in a close fitting hole will optimize this whole thing. Maybe a 2" bolt and thread your insert well onto the threads, or just make the hub longer to force the kiddos to use the right bolt!

Another thing you might consider: you could heat set that aluminum sleeve or press fit it to make it harder to lose

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-08-28T21:20:33.670Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":197,"readers_count":196,"score":69.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470409,"topic_slug":"requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system/470409/5","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3418905,"name":"","username":"TheSnowHatHero","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thesnowhathero/{size}/231822_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-28T21:39:05.755Z","cooked":"
  • why such a long spacer (green arrow). I could understand if it was long enough to reach the heat-set insert, or short enough just to space the 3D printed pulley from the bearing. But I can’t see the reasoning for this in-between length

My goal here was to have maximum length, to make it easier to clamp on when drilling out the main bore, while still having some printed material. My theory was having that printed material would make the bolt’s clamp force makes the assembly less likely to slip relative to itself, minimizing risk of the bolt unscrewing. Whether that theory holds any water is up to people with more experience than I.

  • I would make the pulley as large as possible, while being smaller than the 2" tube OD. Larger pulley means less force on the 3D printed teeth.

Noted; I’ll make sure to do this should we implement this in the future. Thanks!

  • As with all designs of this type, the risk is that the internal thread comes loose or breaks free from the 3D print. In that case, it becomes really difficult to disassemble. Caveat emptor.

I hadn’t thought of this. My main complaint with other designs was loose bolts being difficult to maintenance, but I suppose this is susceptible to something similar.
Thanks for the feedback @nuclearnerd !

I think his last point is a really good one. One way to avoid this is to thread directly into the 3D print. If the threaded insert comes lose, this thing is gonna be a bear to get apart. If the threads in the 3D printed part strip, you’ll be able to get it apart and get that bolt out.

Removing and reapplying the wood screws is at most a five minute process, in my experience. I’m not sure that I trust 3DP threads - have you found success with them?

One other thing to keep in mind regarding maintenance, if the roller has this on each end, it’s essentially captive because the aluminum tubing sticks out into the bearing retainer so this isn’t just a “pull the the bolt on each end and lift it out”.

This is a good point. In intakes, it shouldn’t matter - deflecting a 0.25" poly plate by 0.1" is not incredibly difficult - but I should be using poly plates or an additional spacer in the indexer rollers that use this.
Thanks for the feedback @zog !

I think you can convert the aluminum spacer to 3DP without a lot of risk. There isn’t actually shear there; that’s taken up by the bolt.

This was mostly a pre-assembly worry, since I’ve broken prints with that little material by holding them wrong a few times. I suppose that printing spares would solve this problem just as well.

What’s going to happen is that the bolt is going to try and embed in the pulley as it rotates relative to the pulley axis.

I’m not sure I understand here. Mind clarifying before I say something dumb?

A conical protrusion will optimize your stresses. Make sure you contact as much of the inner race as you can, and consider a metal washer on there to increase the contact area with the plastic.

You mean something like this? Bearing → washer → pulley, left → right.

Screen Shot 2024-08-28 at 4.36.57 PM528×736 155 KB

Using a bolt with an unthreaded section in a close fitting hole will optimize this whole thing. Maybe a 2" bolt and thread your insert well onto the threads, or just make the hub longer to force the kiddos to use the right bolt!

That’s the plan!

Another thing you might consider: you could heat set that aluminum sleeve or press fit it to make it harder to lose

It’s a press, yeah. Thanks for the feedback, @Weldingrod1 !

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-08-28T21:39:05.755Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":189,"readers_count":188,"score":72.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470409,"topic_slug":"requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":22221,"username":"nuclearnerd","name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55003,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2502 Engineering Captain"},"post_url":"/t/requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system/470409/6","custom_user_title":"2502 Engineering Captain","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3418909,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-28T21:52:33.155Z","cooked":"
TheSnowHatHero:

I’m not sure that I trust 3DP threads - have you found success with them?

At the size you’re using (1/4-20 I’m assuming), I would feel pretty comfortable. The friction against the 3D printed material will help retention and you probably aren’t going to torque those bolts to yield or anything.

If you go that route, you will want to look at a printing orientation most likely along the hole axis to print halfway decent threads which is pretty much what I’d expect for this part even without considering threaded holes.

Try to minimize support in the threads and consider running a tap through to clean up if you have any trouble but I’d think you’d be OK otherwise.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-08-28T21:52:33.155Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":152,"readers_count":151,"score":55.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470409,"topic_slug":"requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system","display_username":"Chris Herzog","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40142,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]"},"post_url":"/t/requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system/470409/7","custom_user_title":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3418911,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-28T22:13:06.076Z","cooked":"

Snowhat, the washer you have shown won’t improve the situation at all. It its as large as you can get without touching the non-rotating parts, then it could help. Depends on what your shields/seals look like!

The conical part is the right idea!

Heat set inserts are very strong, in my experience. Not super enthused about tapping 3DPs, though.

When you push on the roller, the bolt tries to rotate relative to the pulley. This applies compressive stresses in the bore of the aluminum (or 3DP pulley bore). If the bolt surface is threaded, its pretty easy to smoosh them into plastic and make the bore bigger/sloppier/damaged. Smooth metal is MUCH harder to smash in to the bore due to much lower stress concentration. The closer the fit, the lower the stress concentration.

Hope that helps…

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-08-28T22:13:06.076Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":147,"readers_count":146,"score":54.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470409,"topic_slug":"requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system/470409/8","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3419083,"name":"","username":"TheSnowHatHero","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thesnowhathero/{size}/231822_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T15:17:50.997Z","cooked":"
Weldingrod1:

[if] its as large as you can get without touching the non-rotating parts, then it could help. Depends on what your shields/seals look like!

Looking at the bearings, this does seem to be the case.

Weldingrod1:

Heat set inserts are very strong, in my experience. Not super enthused about tapping 3DPs, though.

Yeah, that’s about what I had thought. Thanks!

Weldingrod1:

When you push on the roller, the bolt tries to rotate relative to the pulley. This applies compressive stresses in the bore of the aluminum (or 3DP pulley bore). If the bolt surface is threaded, its pretty easy to smoosh them into plastic and make the bore bigger/sloppier/damaged. Smooth metal is MUCH harder to smash in to the bore due to much lower stress concentration. The closer the fit, the lower the stress concentration.

Like so?

Screen Shot 2024-08-29 at 10.16.20 AM1920×1141 77.1 KB

And you’re suggesting fixing it by having the threads start at the insert?

Thanks again for the help!

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-08-29T15:17:50.997Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":129,"readers_count":128,"score":30.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470409,"topic_slug":"requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55003,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2502 Engineering Captain"},"post_url":"/t/requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system/470409/9","custom_user_title":"2502 Engineering Captain","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3419195,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T18:24:06.181Z","cooked":"

The high compressive contact stresses are at the left end of the pulley. You want a smooth surface on the bolt over there.

OP, you might want to check out this thread about stub axles.

How do these 254 mechanisms work? (bearing retention) Technical
This is correct, you kind of need to invert the assembly paradigm. Hubs and dead axles are assembled onto the link, then the rollers are sandwiched by the links and radial screws are inserted. The screenshot I attached didn’t include these so I’ve roughly sketched them in. Cheers, Bryan Red=screw Blue=nut green=counterbore//nut pocket//screw head clearance. [image] [image]

i’m always a little bit surprised at how complicated these things end up.

a fixed cross pin bolt and a greased plastic bushing would work fine for a lot of cases, and it would be literally two parts.

TheSnowHatHero:

over what I currently have?

I’m a big fan of 6328’s solution, because with their setup you can just undo the bolt and slide the roller out without having to force the plates on either side apart, but you do lose a slight amount of roller width with it.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-08-29T19:56:50.316Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":107,"readers_count":106,"score":21.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470409,"topic_slug":"requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system","display_username":"Ian Saam","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-6328-mechanical-advantage-2024-build-thread/442736/302","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC 6328 Mechanical Advantage 2024 Build Thread","clicks":37}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52963,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3128 Strategic Design Lead & Driver"},"post_url":"/t/requesting-design-feedback-stub-axle-roller-system/470409/13","custom_user_title":"3128 Strategic Design Lead & Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3419243,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T20:36:08.963Z","cooked":"
TheSnowHatHero:

I’ve seen similar designs before. What’s the rationale for using that over what I currently have?

Eh, my point wasn’t so much that one design is better or worse, more that the design space has a whole lot of dimensions, and there are lots of different, good, solutions within it, depending on what you need.

you’ve listed low mass and easy assembly as criteria, but i’m sure there are other criteria, e.g. tolerance for friction, stiffness in various directions, strength in various directions, manufacturability, etc, so it’s good to think about those too. i think in general FRC designs tend to have more parts than they need, and less stiffness than they could have, so that might be good to think about too.

for example, if the rest of your assembly needs some way to, say, keep the side plates aligned with respect to each other, then it sure is tempting to try to solve that problem as part of this roller design, using stiffer fittings, or even a full dead axle.

if i had to compare your design to some in the link i shared, i’d suggest that the cantilever stiffness of the pin, relative to its mount, will be lower, which might be a problem and might not, depending on the rest of the assembly and what it does. the stiffness also relies on the tightness of the bolt, and there’s not a good way to make that bolt really really tight, because it’s small in diameter and because it threads into a plastic part. i think in general it’s good to know if your joint needs to be rigid (in which case it should probably be more rigid than this design) or if it can be free in some ways (in which case this design could be simplified a bit). This design has the sort of “in between” character that i think sometimes means that this issue hasn’t been fully explored.

also, as others have mentioned, it is not possible to disassemble without moving the side-plates slightly, which is usually inconvenient.

also it’s worth pointing out the universal solution for really high load joints, which is a sort of tubular pin with a bolted flange: this is generally used industrially for lower velocity joints like excavator arms, but for FRC mechanisms the cycle life requirement is so low that i’m sure it would work fine. it’s a bit harder to fabricate than those pin bolts i pointed out, though.

image1980×2052 251 KB

for the pin bolts, Wilwood has some of these at what seem like reasonable prices to me; they call them “caliper slide pins.” they’re big, about 11/32 pin diameter, but they only weigh a few grams.

wilwood.com

Wilwood Disc Brakes - Search: caliper slide pin

Wilwood Engineering is a manufacturer of high-performance disc brake systems. This page displays search results for: Search: caliper slide pin
